Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Mechanistic Investigation of CO activation by Vanadium Nitrogenase
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division funds Drs. Markus Ribbe and Yilin Hu from the University of California, Irvine to investigate the mechanism of carbon monoxide activation by a unique enzyme. The world is in need of sustainable supplies of carbon fuels while at the same time needs to address the accumulation of carbon wastes which result from the incomplete or complete combustion of carbon fuels. The ability of the enzyme to convert these carbon wastes back into hydrocarbon fuels under mild conditions may be an effective strategy to recycle them back into the usable fuel sources. Drs. Ribbe and Hu are studying how the enzyme may accomplish these goals. Additionally the multidisciplinary nature of the project and the wide varieties of techniques employed are providing abundant opportunities for the education and training of students.


Combined biochemical and spectroscopic approaches are being used to investigate the mechanism of CO activation and reduction by V-nitrogenase, with an emphasis on defining the complete product profile and the reaction pathway of this process. Knowledge acquired through this research is being used to provide mechanistic insights into the reaction of enzymatic CO conversion, enable engineering of nitrogenase-based hydrocarbon-producing microbes, and inform designs of novel CO-and CO2-reducing catalysts. Research and education is being integrated through the project by (i) training undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate researcher on the bench, where all individuals engage in joint efforts that enrich the proposed research through the diversity of learning perspectives, and where underrepresented groups of individuals are incorporated to further improve the diversity of the proposed activities; and (ii) organizing outreach events and designing relevant courses that focus on nitrogenase and related research, where students are introduced to the broad topic of global energy/environmental problems and potential biotechnological solutions to these problems, and where motivated students are recruited for the research activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview: Our world is in dire need of sustainable supplies of carbon fuels; whereas in the same time, it faces the challenge of accumulation of carbon wastes, such as CO (a toxic component in factory or car exhaust) and CO2 (a potent greenhouse gas), which result from the incomplete or complete combustion of carbon fuels. The ability of V-nitrogenase to reduce CO and CO2 to hydrocarbons under ambient conditions suggests the possibility to use this enzyme as a template for future development of effective strategies to recycle the carbon wastes into the usable fuel sources, thereby helping us simultaneously combat the energy- and environment-related problems. The overarching goal of our project is to use combined biochemical and spectroscopic approaches to investigate the mechanism of CO activation and reduction by nitrogenase. Through our studies in the funding period, we have made substantial progress towards this goal by developing effective tools for capturing substrate (CO) or intermediate (CH2O-)-bound states of the nitrogenase-catalyzed CO reduction, which could facilitate generation of more defined intermediates via controlled electron transfer. In addition to these methodological developments, we have identified aldehyde-derived species as intermediates that could be cross-coupled with CO via migratory insertion, which provides an important framework for further mechanistic investigation of CO reduction by nitrogenase.   Knowledge acquired through this research will not only provide mechanistic insights into the enzymatic CO reduction by nitrogenase, but also inform designs of novel CO-and CO2-reducing catalysts in the long run. As such, our proposed study addresses the fundamental chemistry involved in the function of an important biomolecule, which falls well within the research areas supported by the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program.

Intellectual Merit: The inability to generate distinct substrate- or intermediate-bound states has remained a major roadblock for mechanistic investigations of nitrogenase. The outcome of this project has established a novel approach to uncouple the binding of CO or CO-derived intermediate(s) from the subsequent turnover, thereby providing a unique tool for the generation of successive snapshots along the reaction pathway of CO reduction via controlled delivery of electron(s)/proton(s) to CO or CO-derived species. A strategic combination of chemical, biochemical and spectroscopic approaches can now be used to further analyze these snapshots in hopes of elucidating the mechanism the unique enzymatic CO reduction by nitrogenase, which is similar to, yet distinct from that of the industrial Fischer-Tropsch synthesis.

Broader Impacts: In terms of the scientific impact, our work can be appreciated from a broader perspective of the useful products generated by nitrogenase: (i) NH3, a reduced nitrogen source essential for sustaining life on Earth; (ii) H2, a clean energy source important for environmental health; and (iii) hydrocarbons, valuable fuel sources and precursors to important polymers. The fact that nitrogenase is capable of ambient conversion of N2, CO and CO2 to useful products suggests the potential of this enzyme as a template for future development of energy-efficient and environment-friendly strategies to effectively (re)cycle N and C for the benefit of our society. Understanding the mechanism of substrate activation and conversion by nitrogenase, therefore, is crucial for the biotechnological adaptations/applications of this enzyme system, which could address some of the most important challenges our society is facing nowadays. In addition to the scientific impact, the broader impact of our research is perhaps best illustrated by our outreach event, Science Saturdays at UC Irvine, which has been hosted by our labs during the entire period of this project and serves the local SoCal community. Science Saturdays at UC Irvine brings local middle school students to biology and chemistry labs on campus at UCI. Our main goal is to broaden the understanding of science and technology among minorities and the underprivileged kids and to increase their participation in scientific study. The program has been designed by us using NSF guidelines and is headed by our graduate students. Nine events have been completed. Approximately fifty students attended each of the nine events that have been held so far, with visiting students from Julia Lathrop Intermediate School (JLIS) and Carr Intermediate School (CIS) of the Santa Ana Unified School District. More events are planned in the future. Over 90% of the student population of the Santa Ana Unified School District are Latino/Hispanic, with most of them being first-generation Americans and 95% receiving state-mandated free lunches due to low family income. The students and teachers at JLIS and CIS are particularly interested in this experience because their schools have limited facilities for scientific experimentation, and science classes are often taught with no laboratory component. The overwhelmingly positive comments from the visiting students highlight the positive impact of our outreach efforts on motivating young students, particularly the minority and underprivileged students from the SoCal community, to pursue STEM careers in the future.
